author: Legal Correspondent
text:
How can House panel conclude that somebody is guilty of IPC offence, asks Bench

Asking how it can go ahead and conclude someone to be guilty of offences under the Indian Penal Code, the Supreme Court on Friday stayed summons issued by the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly against staff members of a news channel for airing a “sting operation” making allegations against senior minister Azam Khan in connection with the 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots. A Bench of Justices J.S. Khehar and C. Nagappan questioned the veracity of a report by a committee of the Assembly holding the channel employees criminally liable under the Indian Penal Code and acting in contempt of the House.

“How can you conclude that somebody is guilty of IPC offences? Do you have jurisdiction for it? Can you discuss anything in the country and make it part of the House proceedings?” the apex court Bench asked State Additional Advocate General Gaurav Bhatia. Mr. Bhatia responded that the apex court had limited jurisdiction over matters pertaining to the House.

“Our ‘limited’ jurisdiction is vast,” Justice Khehar shot back.

The hearing was based on a petition filed by Supriyo Prasad and others, representing Aaj Tak and India Today TV against the summons directing them to appear before the House Committee on Friday.
title: Supreme Court stays U.P. House summons to TV channel staff
